content.text: Measure, and record in Table 1.1, the distance \(\mathbf{x}\) from the centre of the load to the pivot
Record also the weight of the load.
Calculate, and record in Table 1.1, the value of \(\frac{1}{x}\)
Repeat the steps above, using loads of weight \(P = 3.0 \text{N}\), \(4.0 \text{N}\), \(5.0 \text{N}\) and \(6.0 \text{N}\). Record all the values of \(P\), \(x\) and \(\frac{1}{x}\) in Table 1.1.
路 Place the metre rule on the pivot at the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark
路 Place the object Q with its centre on the metre rule at the 90.0 cm mark
路 Place a load of weight \(P = 2.0 \text{N}\) on the metre rule
路 Adjust the position of the load so that the metre rule is as near as possible to being balanced and horizontal
Plot a graph of \(P / \mathsf{N}\) (y-axis) against \(\frac{1}{\mathsf{x}} /\frac{1}{\mathsf{cm}}\) (x-axis). Start both axes at the origin (0,0)
In this experiment, \(x_{\mathrm{max}}\), the maximum possible value for \(x\) is \(50.0 \text{cm}\). Calculate \(\frac{1}{x_{\mathrm{max}}}\)
Use the graph to determine the minimum value of \(P\) required to balance the metre rule in this experiment. Show clearly on the graph how you determined this value
minimum value of \(P =\)
In this experiment, you will investigate the balancing of a metre rule
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1
Measure the current \(I_{1}\) in the circuit
Measure the potential difference \(V_{1}\) across lamp \(\mathsf{L}_{1}\)
Switch off
Calculate the resistance \(R_{1}\) of the filament of lamp \(\mathsf{L}_{1}\). Use the equation \(R_{1} = \frac{V_{1}}{I_{1}}\). Include the unit
Switch on
Disconnect the voltmeter. Connect lamp \(\mathsf{L}_{2}\) in series with lamp \(\mathsf{L}_{1}\). Connect the voltmeter across lamp \(\mathsf{L}_{2}\). Switch on
Measure the current \(I_{2}\) in the circuit
Measure the potential difference \(V_{2}\) across lamp \(\mathsf{L}_{2}\)
Switch off
Calculate the resistance \(R_{2}\) of the filament of lamp \(\mathsf{L}_{2}\). Use the equation \(R_{2} = \frac{V_{2}}{I_{2}}\)
Disconnect the voltmeter. Connect lamp \(\mathsf{L}_{3}\) in series with lamps \(\mathsf{L}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{L}_{2}\). Connect the voltmeter across lamp \(\mathsf{L}_{3}\). Switch on
Measure the current \(I_{3}\) in the circuit
Measure the potential difference \(V_{3}\) across lamp \(\mathsf{L}_{3}\)
Switch off
Calculate the resistance \(R_{3}\) of the filament of lamp \(\mathsf{L}_{3}\). Use the equation \(R_{3} = \frac{V_{3}}{I_{3}}\)
Calculate \(R_{1} + R_{2} + R_{3}\). Give your answer to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment
Some students make suggestions about the results of the experiment
Suggestion \(\mathbf{A}\colon R_{1} + R_{2} + R_{3}\) should be equal to \(3\times R_{1}\)
Suggestion \(\mathbf{B}\colon R_{1} + R_{2} + R_{3}\) should be less than \(3\times R_{1}\)
Suggestion \(\mathbf{C}\colon R_{1} + R_{2} + R_{3}\) should be greater than \(3\times R_{1}\)
State which suggestion, \(\mathbf{A}\), \(\mathbf{B}\) or \(\mathbf{C}\), agrees with your results. Justify your answer by reference to your results
statement
justification
A student investigates whether the statement in (e) is always true for the same three lamps connected in series
State a variable that he changes and how he changes the variable. You are **not** required to do this extra experiment
variable to change
method of changing the variable
In this experiment, you will determine the resistances of filament lamps
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1
Fig. 2.1

Draw a line \(10\mathrm{cm}\) long near the middle of the ray-trace sheet. Label the line \(\mathbf{MR}\). Draw a normal to this line that passes through the centre of \(\mathbf{MR}\). Label the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\). Label the point at which \(\mathbf{NL}\) crosses \(\mathbf{MR}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{B}\)

Draw a line \(7.0 \text{cm}\) long from \(\mathbf{B}\) at an angle of incidence \(i = 30^\circ\) to the normal below \(\mathbf{MR}\) and to the left of the normal. Label the end of this line \(\mathbf{A}\)
Place a pin \(\mathsf{P}_1\) on line \(\mathbf{AB}\) at a distance \(6.0 \text{cm}\) from \(\mathbf{B}\)
Place a pin \(\mathsf{P}_2\) on line \(\mathbf{AB}\) close to \(\mathbf{MR}\)
Place the reflecting face of the mirror vertically on the line \(\mathbf{MR}\)
View the images of pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) from the direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 3.1

Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) some distance apart so that pin \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_2\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) all appear exactly behind pin \(\mathsf{P}_4\). Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\)
Remove the pins and the mirror and draw the line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\)
Continue the line until it extends at least \(7.0 \text{cm}\) beyond \(\mathbf{MR}\)
Draw a line from \(\mathsf{P}_1\) to \(\mathbf{MR}\) that meets \(\mathbf{MR}\) at a right angle. Measure and record the length \(a\) of this line
Draw a line from the point labelled \(\mathbf{Y}\) to \(\mathbf{MR}\) that meets \(\mathbf{MR}\) at a right angle. Measure and record the length \(b\) of this line
Replace pin \(\mathsf{P}_1\) on line \(\mathbf{AB}\) at a distance \(6.0 \text{cm}\) from \(\mathbf{B}\)
Place pin \(\mathsf{P}_2\) \(1.0 \text{cm}\) to the right of its position in part (a)
Repeat the steps in part (b)
Label with the letter \(\mathbf{Y}\) the point where the two lines cross beyond \(\mathbf{MR}\)
Replace the mirror on \(\mathbf{MR}\). Place pin \(\mathsf{P}_1\) on the normal at a distance \(6.0 \text{cm}\) from the front of the mirror
View the image of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) in the mirror
Place pin \(\mathsf{P}_2\) on the normal behind the mirror

Adjust the position of \(\mathsf{P}_2\) along the normal so that the image of the bottom of the pin \(\mathsf{P}_1\) seen in the mirror and the top of pin \(\mathsf{P}_2\) seen over the mirror appear as one pin when viewed from all angles in front of the mirror
Label the position of \(\mathsf{P}_2\)
Remove the pins and the mirror
Measure the distance \(x\) along the normal between \(\mathsf{P}_2\) and the mirror
A student carries out this experiment with care
Suggest a practical reason why the results may not be accurate
In this experiment you will investigate the position of the image in a plane mirror
Carry out the following instructions, using the separate ray-trace sheet provided. You may refer to Fig. 3.1 for guidance

A student investigates the effect of the colour of the surface of a metal container on the rate of loss of heat from the container. She knows that black surfaces are better radiators of thermal energy than white surfaces and wants to investigate the effect of other colours
The following apparatus is available:
metal containers each with the outer surface painted a different colour
a thermometer
a stop-watch
a supply of hot water
She can also use other apparatus and materials that are usually available in a school laboratory
Plan an experiment to investigate the effect of the colour of the surface of a metal container on the rate of loss of heat from the container. You are **not** required to carry out this investigation
You should:
draw a diagram of the apparatus used
explain briefly how you would carry out the investigation
state the key variables that you would control
draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)
explain how you would use your readings to reach a conclusion
